questiontext.text:
We have two vectors \(\vec{u}\) and \(\vec{v}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) given by \[ \begin{aligned} \vec{u} &= {@U@} \\ \vec{v} &= {@V@} \end{aligned}. \] Calculate \(\vec{u}+\vec{v}\).

\(\vec{u}+\vec{v} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Consider a memoryless binary channel with channel probabilities \[\mathcal{P}(0\text{ recieved} \mid 0\text{ sent }) = {@prob_00@}, \qquad \mathcal{P}(1 \text{ recieved} \mid 1\text{ sent }) = {@prob_11@}.\] If codewords from the binary code {000, 100, 111} are being sent over this channel, use the maximum likelihood decoding rule to decode the following received words:


(a) 010 = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]


(b) 011 = [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]


(c) 001 = [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Let \(C\) be the code in \(\mathbb{F}^7_5\) with generator-matrix \[G = {@G@}\]

a) Calculate the check matrix, \(H\), for this code, giving your answer in standard form for a check matrix.


\(H = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]



Let \(C_1 = \langle({@c1[1][1]@}, {@c1[1][2]@}, {@c1[1][3]@}, {@c1[1][4]@})\rangle\), and \(C_2 = \langle({@c2_1[1][1]@}, {@c2_1[1][2]@}, {@c2_1[1][3]@}, {@c2_1[1][4]@}), ({@c2_2[1][1]@}, {@c2_2[1][2]@}, {@c2_2[1][3]@}, {@c2_2[1][4]@}),({@c2_3[1][1]@}, {@c2_3[1][2]@}, {@c2_3[1][3]@}, {@c2_3[1][4]@})\rangle\), both codes in \(\mathbb{F}^4_3\).

b) Find the parameters, \([n, k, d]\), for each code.


\(C_1\): [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

\(C_2\): [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: Well done, you have correctly calculated the check matrix \(H\).

falsefeedback.text: Your answer for \(H\) is incorrect. You should have noticed that \(G\) is given in the standard form \((I_k \mid A)\) and therefore we can use Proposition 4.5 to find \(H\) in the standard form for a check matrix as \((-A^t \mid I_{n-k})\).

truefeedback.text: You have correctly calculated the first part of \(H\) as \(-A^t\)

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly calculated the first part of \(H\). You should have found the negative transpose of \(A\) from \(G\) as \[-A^t = {@H_A@}\]

truefeedback.text: You have correctly calculated the second part of \(H\) as \(I_{n-k}\)

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly calculated the second part of \(H\). You should have found that \(n - k = 4\), and so we get \[I_{n-k} = I_4 = {@H_I@}\].

truefeedback.text: You have correctly identified \(C_1\) as a {@c1_param@} code.

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly identified the parameters, \([n, k, d]\), of \(C_1\).
You have incorrectly identified \(n\). Remember we are working in \(\mathbb{F}^n_q = \mathbb{F}^4_3\).

You have incorrectly identified \(k\). We find \(k\) as the dimension of the code, which is the number of vectors in a basis. Since \(C_1\) is the span of one non-zero element, which must be linearly independent by itself, this element gives a basis for \(C_1\). Therefore, \(k\) in this case should be 1.
You have incorrectly calculated \(d\). We can find the minimum distance here simply by taking the weight, which in this case is {@d_1@}, as all scalar multiples of this word have the same weight.

truefeedback.text: You have correctly identified \(C_2\) as a {@c2_param@} code.

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly identified the parameters, \([n, k, d]\), of \(C_2\).
You have incorrectly identified \(n\). Remember we are working in \(\mathbb{F}^n_q = \mathbb{F}^4_3\).

You have incorrectly identified \(k\). We find \(k\) as the dimension of the code, which is the number of vectors in a basis. The set given is a spanning set, but not a basis, as for example we can write \(({@c2_3[1][1]@}, {@c2_3[1][2]@}, {@c2_3[1][3]@}, {@c2_3[1][4]@})\) as a linear combination of \(({@c2_1[1][1]@}, {@c2_1[1][2]@}, {@c2_1[1][3]@}, {@c2_1[1][4]@})\) and \(({@c2_2[1][1]@}, {@c2_2[1][2]@}, {@c2_2[1][3]@}, {@c2_2[1][4]@})\). We get a basis once we remove \(({@c2_3[1][1]@}, {@c2_3[1][2]@}, {@c2_3[1][3]@}, {@c2_3[1][4]@})\) from the spanning set as the other two vectors are linearly independent, as can be seen by considering the positions of the zeros. The size of this basis, and the correct value for \(k\), is therefore \({@c2_param[1][2]@}\).

You have incorrectly calculated \(d\). We can form a generator matrix for \(C_2\) using our two basis vectors, which can be easily row reduced into standard form (or standard form for a check matrix). We can now use Proposition 4.5 to find a check matrix in standard form (or standard form for a generator matrix), and apply Theorem 4.11 to the columns of this check matrix. In this case, we find the smallest number of linearly dependent columns is \({@d_2@}\).

questiontext.text:
\(\textbf{1.1}\) Calculate the information rates and relative minimum distances of the following:


(i) \(C_1\): A \({@q1@}\)-ary \(({@n1@},{@M@},{@d1@})\) code

\(R(C_1) = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

\(\delta(C_1) = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]


(ii) \(C_2\): A \({@q2@}\)-ary \([{@n2@},{@k2@},{@d2@}]\) code

\(R(C_2) = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

\(\delta(C_2) = \) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: You have correctly calculated the information rate of \(C_1\)

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly calculated the information rate of \(C_1\)

truefeedback.text: You have correctly calculated the relative minimum distance of \(C_1\)

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly calculated the relative minimum distance of \(C_1\)

truefeedback.text: It seems as though you have forgotten to take the logarithm base \(q\) of \(M\) before dividing by \(n\)
The value you entered for the information rate is actually the correct value for the relative minimum distance. Check you haven't entered your answers the wrong way around.
The information rate should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is larger than 1
The information rate should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is smaller than 0

falsefeedback.text: Remember the formula for the information rate of a \(q\)-ary \((n,M,d)\) code is \(R(C) = \frac{\text{log}_q(M)}{n}\)

truefeedback.text: It seems as though you have forgotten to take 1 away from \(d\) before dividing by \(n\)
The value you entered for the relative minimum distance is actually the correct value for the information rate. Check you haven't entered your answers the wrong way around.
The relative minimum distance should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is larger than 1
The relative minimum distance should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is smaller than 0

falsefeedback.text: Remember the formula for the relative minimum distance of a \(q\)-ary \((n,M,d)\) code is \(\delta(C) = \frac{d-1}{n}\)

truefeedback.text: You have correctly calculated the information rate of \(C_2\)

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly calculated the information rate of \(C_2\)

truefeedback.text: You have correctly calculated the relative minimum distance of \(C_2\)

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly calculated the relative minimum distance of \(C_2\)

truefeedback.text: The value you entered for the information rate is actually the correct value for the relative minimum distance. Check you haven't entered your answers the wrong way around.
The information rate should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is larger than 1
The information rate should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is smaller than 0

falsefeedback.text: Remember the formula for the information rate of a \(q\)-ary \([n,k,d]\) code is \(R(C) = \frac{k}{n}\)

truefeedback.text: It seems as though you have forgotten to take 1 away from \(d\) before dividing by \(n\)
The value you entered for the relative minimum distance is actually the correct value for the information rate. Check you haven't entered your answers the wrong way around.
The relative minimum distance should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is larger than 1
The relative minimum distance should be a number between 0 and 1. Your answer is smaller than 0

falsefeedback.text: Remember the formula for the relative minimum distance of a \(q\)-ary \([n,k,d]\) code is \(\delta(C) = \frac{d-1}{n}\)

questiontext.text:
\(\textbf{2.1.}\) Calculate values for the following:

(i) \(A_{@q1@}({@n1@},{@d1@}) =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

(ii) \(A_{@q2@}({@n2@},{@d2@}) \leq\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

(iii) \(B_{@q3@}({@n3@},{@d3@}) =\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]


\(\textbf{2.2.}\) Fill in the values which make following statements to be correct:

(i) \(B_{@q4@}({@n4@},\) [[input:ans4]] \()\) \( = {@a4@}\) [[validation:ans4]]

(ii) \(A_{@q5@}(\) [[input:ans5]] \(,{@d5@})\) \( \leq {@a5@}\) [[validation:ans5]]

(iii) \(B_{@q6@}({@n6@}\) , [[input:ans6]] \()\) \( = {@a6@}\) [[validation:ans6]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
You have incorrectly calculated (i)

We can use the third condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,n) = A_q(n,n) = q.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[q = {@q1@}.\]

You have incorrectly calculated (ii)

We can use the first condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,d) \leq A_q(n,d) \leq q^n \text{ for all } 1 \leq d \leq n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[q^n = {@a2@}.\]

You have incorrectly calculated (iii)

We can use the second condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,1) = A_q(n,1) = q^n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[q^n = {@a3@}.\]

You have incorrectly calculated (ii)

\[B_q(n,d) \leq A_q(n,d) \leq q^n \text{ for all } 1 \leq d \leq n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[q^n = {@a2@}.\]

You have incorrectly calculated (iii)

We can use the second condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,1) = A_q(n,1) = q^n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[q^n = {@a3@}.\]

You have incorrectly identified \(d \) in (i)

We can use the second condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,1) = A_q(n,1) = q^n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[d = {@d4@}.\]

You have incorrectly identified \(n\) in (ii)

We can use the first condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,d) \leq A_q(n,d) \leq q^n \text{ for all } 1 \leq d \leq n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[n = {@n5@}.\]

You have incorrectly identified \(d\) in (iii)

We can use the third condition of Theorem 3.1 here. Remember that this states that for \(q \geq 2\) a prime power:

\[B_q(n,n) = A_q(n,n) = q.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[d6 = {@d6@}.\]

You have incorrectly identified \(n\) in (ii)

\[B_q(n,d) \leq A_q(n,d) \leq q^n \text{ for all } 1 \leq d \leq n.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

\[n = {@n5@}.\]

\[B_q(n,n) = A_q(n,n) = q.\]

Substituting the correct values into this gives

questiontext.text:
\(\textbf{3.1}\) Use the Gilbert–Varshamov bound to verify the following statements:

(i) The \([{@n1@},{@k1@},{@d1@}]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q1@}\) exists. [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

(ii) The \([{@n2@},{@k2@},{@d2@}]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q2@}\) does not exist. [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

(iii) The \([{@n3@},{@k3@},{@d3@}]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q3@}\) exists. [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]


\(\textbf{3.2}\) Using the same bound, find the largest value of \(d\) for which there exists a \([{@n@}, {@k@}, d]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q@}\)

\(d =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
You have incorrectly identifies (i) as {@ans1@}

Remember, the Gilbert–Varshamov bound is as follows:

\[\sum_{i=0}^{d-2}{n-1 \choose i}(q-1)^i < q^{n-k}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[{@lhs1@} < {@rhs1@}.\]

This means that (i) must be {@a@}

You have incorrectly identifies (ii) as {@ans2@}

Remember, the Gilbert–Varshamov bound is as follows:

\[\sum_{i=0}^{d-2}{n-1 \choose i}(q-1)^i < q^{n-k}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[{@lhs2@} < {@rhs2@}.\]

This means that (ii) must be {@b@}

You have incorrectly identifies (iii) as {@ans3@}

Remember, the Gilbert–Varshamov bound is as follows:

\[\sum_{i=0}^{d-2}{n-1 \choose i}(q-1)^i < q^{n-k}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[{@lhs3@} < {@rhs3@}.\]

This means that (iii) must be {@c@}

You have incorrectly identifies (ii) as {@ans2@}

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[{@lhs2@} < {@rhs2@}.\]

This means that (ii) must be {@b@}

You have incorrectly identifies (iii) as {@ans3@}

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[{@lhs3@} < {@rhs3@}.\]

This means that (iii) must be {@c@}

truefeedback.text: You have correctly identified the maximum value of \(d\) as {@d@}

falsefeedback.text: You have incorrectly identified the maximum value of \(d\)

truefeedback.text: Your answer is only off by one.

Remember we are looking for the largest value of \(d\) for which the Gilbert–Varshamov bound is satisfied. This bound is as follows:

\[\sum_{i=0}^{d-2}{n-1 \choose i}(q-1)^i < q^{n-k}.\]

Substituting your value of \(d\) into this gives us

\[{@sum1@} < {@rhs@}.\]

This obviously does not hold and so a lower value of \(d\) is needed.

falsefeedback.text:
Remember we are looking for the largest value of \(d\) for which the Gilbert–Varshamov bound is satisfied. This bound is as follows:

\[\sum_{i=0}^{d-2}{n-1 \choose i}(q-1)^i < q^{n-k}.\]

Substituting your value of \(d\) into this gives us

\[{@sum1@} < {@rhs@}.\]

This does hold, however, it will also hold for a larger value of \(d\).

questiontext.text:
\(\textbf{4.1}\) Let C be a linear \([{@n1@},{@k1@},{@d1@}]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q1@}\) with \(\textbf{c}\), a codeword in \(C\), with \(\lvert \text{Supp}(\textbf{c})\rvert = {@d1@}\). Calculate the following parameters for \(\text{Res}(C,\textbf{c})\):

(i) \(n =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

(ii) \(k =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

(iii) \(d \geq \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]


\(\textbf{4.2}\) Use the Griesmer bound to find the lower bounds on \(n\) for the following linear codes:

(i) The \([n,{@k2@},{@d2@}]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q2@}\)

\(n \geq\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]]

(ii) The \([n,{@k3@},{@d3@}]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q3@}\)

\(n \geq\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]


\(\textbf{4.3}\) Using the same bound, find the largest value of \(d\) possible for a \([{@n4@},{@k4@},d]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_{@q4@}\)

\(d =\) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
You have incorrectly calculated \(n\) in (i).

Here we can use Lemma 5.1 which tells us that when \(C\) is an \([n,k,d]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_q\) and \(\textbf{c}\) is a codeword in \(C\) with weight \(w = d\), then \(\text{Res}(C,\textbf{c})\) is an \([n-d, k-1, d']\) code, where \(d' \geq \lceil\frac{d}{q}\rceil\)

You have incorrectly calculated \(k\) in (i).

Here we can use Lemma 5.1 which tells us that when \(C\) is an \([n,k,d]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_q\) and \(\textbf{c}\) is a codeword in \(C\) with weight \(w = d\), then \(\text{Res}(C,\textbf{c})\) is an \([n-d, k-1, d']\) code, where \(d' \geq \lceil\frac{d}{q}\rceil\)

You have incorrectly calculated \(d\) in (iii).

Here we can use Lemma 5.1 which tells us that when \(C\) is an \([n,k,d]\) code over \(\mathbb{F}_q\) and \(\textbf{c}\) is a codeword in \(C\) with weight \(w = d\), then \(\text{Res}(C,\textbf{c})\) is an \([n-d, k-1, d']\) code, where \(d' \geq \lceil\frac{d}{q}\rceil\)

You have incorrectly calculated \(k\) in (ii).

See above for information about Lemma 5.1

You have incorrectly calculated \(d\) in (iii).

See above for information about Lemma 5.1
You have incorrectly calculated the bound for \(n\) in (i)
You have incorrectly calculated the bound for \(n\) in (ii)

Your bound is too high

Remember we are using the Griesmer bound which is as follows:

\[n \geq \sum_{i=0}^{k-1}{\lceil\frac{d}{q^i}\rceil}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[n \geq {@n2@}.\]

\[n \geq \sum_{i=0}^{k-1}{\lceil\frac{d}{q^i}\rceil}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[n \geq {@n2@}.\]

\[n \geq \sum_{i=0}^{k-1}{\lceil\frac{d}{q^i}\rceil}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[n \geq {@n3@}.\]

falsefeedback.text:
Your bound is too low

Remember we are using the Griesmer bound which is as follows:

\[n \geq \sum_{i=0}^{k-1}{\lceil\frac{d}{q^i}\rceil}.\]

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[n \geq {@n2@}.\]
You have incorrectly calculated the bound for \(n\) in (ii)

Substituting the correct values into the bound leaves us with the inequality

\[n \geq {@n3@}.\]

questiontext.text:
Let A = {1,2,3,4} and let \(x\) = {@x@}, \(y\) = {@y@}, \(z\) = {@z@}. Find the following Hamming distances:


\(d(x,y)\) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]


\(d(x,z)\) = [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]


\(d(y,z)\) = [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
Your answer for d(x,y) is incorrect

Remember, the Hamming distance is the number of places at which x and y differ.

For example, given A = {0, 1}, and letting x = 101 and y = 110, we can see that the first digit is a 1 for both x and y, but then the next two digits differ.

So in this example, the hamming distance d(x,y), would be 2.

Your answer for d(x,z) is incorrect

Remember, the Hamming distance is the number of places at which x and y differ.

For example, given A = {0, 1}, and letting x = 101 and y = 110, we can see that the first digit is a 1 for both x and y, but then the next two digits differ.

So in this example, the hamming distance d(x,y), would be 2.

Your answer for d(z,y) is incorrect

Remember, the Hamming distance is the number of places at which x and y differ.

For example, given A = {0, 1}, and letting x = 101 and y = 110, we can see that the first digit is a 1 for both x and y, but then the next two digits differ.

So in this example, the hamming distance d(x,y), would be 2.

Your answer for d(x,z) is incorrect

See above for a correct example.

Your answer for d(x,z) is incorrect

See above for a correct example.

questiontext.text:
We have two vectors \(\vec{u}\) and \(\vec{v}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^4\) given by \[\vec{u} = {@u@} \qquad \vec{v} = {@v@}\] Find the lengths of the two vectors \(\vec{u}\) and \(\vec{v}\) in \( \mathbb{R}^4\)

\(|\vec{u}| = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

\(|\vec{v}| = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]


Now use your answers to find the angle \( \theta \in [0, \pi]\) between them to 3.d.p

\(\theta = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
You have incorrectly calculated |\(\vec{u}\)|

Remember, to do this you must find the dot product of \(\vec{u}\) with itself, and then take the square root of the result.

To find the dot product of a vector, you multiply the components, and then add them all up. Below is an example: \[\pmatrix{a \\ b \\ c \\ d}\cdot\pmatrix{e \\ f \\ g \\ h} = ae+bf+cg+dh\]

For this part of the question, the dot product of \(\vec{u}\) with itself gives \({@dot_u@}\).
Square rooting this then gives \({@len_u@}\)

You have incorrectly calculated |\(\vec{v}\)|

Remember, to do this you must find the dot product of \(\vec{v}\) with itself, and then take the square root of the result.

To find the dot product of a vector, you multiply the components, and then add them all up. Below is an example: \[\pmatrix{a \\ b \\ c \\ d}\cdot\pmatrix{e \\ f \\ g \\ h} = ae+bf+cg+dh\]

For this part of the question, the dot product of \(\vec{v}\) with itself gives \({@dot_v@}\).
Square rooting this then gives \({@len_v@}\)

You have also incorrectly calculated |\(\vec{v}\)|

This is done in the same way as the last part of the question. An explanation on how this is done has been given above

For this part of the question, the dot product of \(\vec{v}\) with itself gives \({@dot_v@}\).
Square rooting this then gives \({@len_v@}\)
You have incorrectly calculated \(\theta\)

truefeedback.text:
The correct formula has been used, but with incorrect values for the vector lengths

If you use the correct values for the vector lengths, you should get {@theta@}

falsefeedback.text:
The formula you should have used was \[\cos\theta = \frac{\vec{u}\cdot\vec{v}}{|\vec{u}||\vec{v}|}\]

This would have given the correct answer of {@theta@}

questiontext.text:
Write the following vectors in polar form, i.e. in the form \(\ r\left(\begin{array}{c}\cos(\theta) \\ \sin(\theta)\end{array}\right)\ \) for some positive real number \(r\) and some angle \(0\leq\theta < 2\pi\)


(a)\(\ {@a@} = \) [[input:ans1]]\(\ \)[[input:ans2]][[validation:ans1]][[validation:ans2]]

(b)\(\ {@b@} = \) [[input:ans3]]\(\ \)[[input:ans4]][[validation:ans3]][[validation:ans4]]

(c)\(\ {@c@} = \) [[input:ans5]]\(\ \)[[input:ans6]][[validation:ans5]][[validation:ans6]]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
